docs.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the workers at Avondale shipyard voted to join a union, with hundreds of them cheering wildly outside the company's headquarters along the Mississippi River when the vote count was announced. Today, there is still no union at the shipyard. The 50,000 pages of documents -- furious charges and countercharges -- stacked in the offices of the National Labor Relations Board are evidence of what took place instead: one of the longest, most heavily litigated unionization fights in the board's history.

headline.main: 5 Years After Workers' Vote, Shipyard Holds Off a Union

docs.abstract: Workers at Avondale shipyard in New Orleans remain without a union five years after voting to join one; Avondale battle is one of most heavily litigated unionization fights in history of National Labor Relations Board; labor leaders and even some Government officials point to it as proof that nation's labor laws are cumbersome and replete with loopholes and that companies intent on keeping unions out can dismiss union supporters and use other illegal tactics to beat back organizing drives and make mockery of right to organize; say employers create delays because they realize that organizing drives can fizzle in five years it can take for courts to order company to recognize union that won unionization election; Federal officials say scores of union-organizing cases are caught up in legal limbo, as companies file appeal after appeal; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For Daniel Shumate, a 32-year-old parolee, it's another chance to get his life on track. For Melissa Bolton, 23 and also a parolee, it's an opportunity to show that a woman can handle heavy work in the oilfields. For Ruben Garza, 20, it's a way to break out of toiling at minimum wage. And for Ben Hilgreth, 21, a college student, it's a way to build up a stake that he can use to invest. While their goals vary, these four share a single dream: to make it in one of the most physically demanding, dangerous and at times technically challenging jobs around -- being a ''roughneck,'' or laborer, on an oil rig.

headline.main: Roughnecks Of Distinction; Oilfield Workers Acquire Status in Labor Shortage

docs.abstract: Demand for oilfield workes has increased for first time since oil prices hit bottom in late 1980's; industry still needs strong workers who can take punishing 12-hour shifts and stay mentally alert despite new technology; lack of good entry-level workers has caused many drilling companies to begin their own training programs with benefits; graphs; photos (M)
